title: FOSSIL PALMS (ARECACEAE, CORYPHOIDEAE) ASSOCIATED WITH JUVENILE HERBIVOROUS DINOSAURS IN THE UPPER CRETACEOUS AGUJA FORMATION, BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK, TEXAS
abstract: Seeds of two palm species conforming to the extant genus Sabal have been recovered from the Campanian (Upper Cretaceous) Aguja Formation of Big Bend National Park, Texas: Sabal bigbendense sp. nov. and Sabal bracknellense (Chandler) Mai. These remains, found together with anatomically preserved palm stems, augment previous reports of Sabalites ungeri (Lesq.) Dorf leaves from the same formation. The co-occurrence of palm seeds with numerous juvenile hadrosaur and ceratopsian bones indicates that palms closely related to modern cabbage palms may have provided fodder and shelter for young herbivorous dinosaurs. The distribution of these and other Late Cretaceous palm fossils is reviewed.

abstract.text: Seeds of two palm species conforming to the extant genus Sabal have been recovered from the Campanian (Upper Cretaceous) Aguja Formation of Big Bend National Park, Texas: Sabal bigbendense sp. nov. and Sabal bracknellense (Chandler) Mai. These remains, found together with anatomically preserved palm stems, augment previous reports of Sabalites ungeri (Lesq.) Dorf leaves from the same formation. The co-occurrence of palm seeds with numerous juvenile hadrosaur and ceratopsian bones indicates that palms closely related to modern cabbage palms may have provided fodder and shelter for young herbivorous dinosaurs. The distribution of these and other Late Cretaceous palm fossils is reviewed.

body_text.text: Big Bend National Park in southwestern Texas preserves a continuous sequence of Upper Cretaceous (Campanian-Maastrichtian) through Lower Tertiary (Paleocene) continental strata. These strata contain a varied terrestrial and aquatic vertebrate fauna of Judithian age (;79-74 Ma; Lehman and Busbey 2007) and a diverse assemblage of dicotyledonous and coniferous woods (Wheeler 1991; Wheeler et al. 1994; Wheeler and Lehman 2000 Lehman and Wheeler 2001) . Monocotyledons, represented by leaves, seed casts, and petrified stems and roots, also occur commonly in the Campanian Aguja Formation and include some of the oldest records for coryphoid palms. The seeds and stems co-occur with bones of juvenile hadrosaur and ceratopsian dinosaurs at multiple localities.

In this article we describe the Aguja palm seed and stem remains, which, along with the leaf remains already described by Dorf (1939) , allow recognition of the modern coryphoid palm genus Sabal in the Upper Cretaceous. Sabal Adanson ex Guersent, with 15 extant species, is now confined to Mexico, the Caribbean Islands, Bermuda, and the southeastern United States (Zona 1990 ), but fossil records indicate that the genus was more widespread in the Northern Hemisphere, occurring in midlatitudes of North America and Europe and possibly also in Asia during the Tertiary (reviewed in Manchester 1999; Dransfield et al. 2008) . Although Sabal was previously recognized based on seeds as old as Early Eocene (;52 Ma), the Aguja occurrence extends the minimum age of this genus back to the Campanian (;77 Ma). The significance of fossil Sabal from the Aguja Formation is considered in relation to the phytogeography of this genus and the ecological co-occurrence with herbivorous dinosaurs.

The Aguja Formation contains two terrestrial intervals referred to informally as the lower and upper shale members (Lehman and Busbey 2007) . Both the lower shale member and the lowermost part of the upper shale member consist primarily of dark organic-rich shale, lignite, and coal that accumulated in poorly drained brackish-water marshes or swamps close to the shoreline. These deposits interfinger with coastal strand plain and marine shelf deposits of the Pen Formation. The upper part of the upper shale member consists of drab fluvial floodplain deposits, primarily olive, yellow, and gray mudstone interbedded with lenticular stream channel sandstone. These sediments accumulated in better-drained freshwater alluvial environments some distance landward of the shoreline. Most of the diverse fossil wood assemblage thus far documented for the Aguja Formation has been recovered from the upper shale member, including a unique association of in situ tree stumps (Agujoxylon olacaceoides and Metcalfeoxylon kirtlandense) that demonstrates that dicot trees were dominant canopy-forming elements in some Late Cretaceous forests at lower latitudes of western North America (Lehman and Wheeler 2001) .

Palm leaf impressions and permineralized stem fragments are found throughout the Aguja Formation, as well as in the overlying Javelina Formation. Baghai (1996) reported pollen having suggested affinities with the palm family (Arecaceae; e.g., Arecipites Wodehouse, Palmaepollenites Potonié, Monocolpopollenites Thomson & Pflug, Sabalpollenites Thiergart in Raatz) from throughout the same stratigraphic interval. However, the palm seed collection sites described herein and the best-preserved in situ palm stems are confined to the lower Int. J. Plant Sci. 171(6):679-689. 2010. Ó 2010 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved. 1058-5893/2010/17106-0009$15.00 DOI: 10.1086/653688 50 m of the Aguja upper shale member ( fig. 1 ). Vertebrate biostratigraphy (Rowe et al. 1992) and radiometric age determinations (Befus et al. 2008) indicate that the upper shale member of the Aguja Formation is Middle to Late Campanian in age.

The fossil seeds and stems described herein were collected at four sites near the western border of Big Bend National Park. Two localities are on the southern side of Rattlesnake Mountain, about 1 km apart and 2 km north of Maverick Road. These two sites are Texas Memorial Museum (TMM) vertebrate fossil localities TMM 42534 (20 m above the base of the upper shale member) and TMM 43163 (40 m above the base of the upper shale member), equivalent to Florida Museum of Natural History Paleobotanical Collection (UF) localities 402 and 403, respectively. Two additional sites are TMM 41917 (UF401), near Bruja Canyon, and WPA-1 (UF404), a site originally excavated as part of a Works Progress Administration (WPA) project in the 1930s (Lehman 2007 ). Exact locality information and maps for the collection sites are available at the Florida Museum of Natural History Paleobotanical Collection, University of Florida, Gainesville, and at the Vertebrate Paleontology Laboratory of the Texas Memorial Museum in Austin.
Sabal bigbendense sp. nov. ( Fig. 2A-2H )

Diagnosis. Seeds subglobose-oblate, rounded dorsally; proximal surface with a broad circular depression that is domed in the center. Seeds 12.0-13.9 mm in diameter and 11.0-11.1 mm in height. Surface smooth to wrinkled. Germination operculum small (2.0 mm), circular, positioned equatorially to supraequatorially.
Specimens. Holotype, here designated:

Localities. TMM 42534 and TMM 43163. These suboblate seeds conform to Sabal in having a circular outline; a circular rim surrounding a basal scar including the Fig. 1 Geographic and stratigraphic location of selected palm-bearing sites in the Aguja Formation of Big Bend National Park, Texas. The map shows positions of measured stratigraphic sections (1-8), also shown on a restored cross section of the intertonguing Aguja and Pen formations. Sites discussed in the text near Rattlesnake Mountain (RM) are shown, as is the approximate stratigraphic level of Dorf's (1939) palm collection site. The stratigraphic section of the Aguja Formation at Rattlesnake Mountain shows informal subdivisions and levels of palm-bearing Texas Memorial Museum (TMM) vertebrate fossil sites and the WPA-1 ceratopsian bone bed described by Lehman (2007) . hilum; a thin, smooth seed coat; and a small circular plug of embryo protrusion in equatorial to supraequatorial position. These are the largest of all fossil Sabal seeds known, the next biggest being those of the Eocene London Clay species Sabal grandisperma Reid & Chandler (1933;  10 mm in diameter). Among extant species of Sabal, seeds of a similarly large size occur in Sabal pumos (Kunth) Burret, Sabal rosei (Cook) Beccari, and Sabal uresana Trelease ( fig. 3 ; Zona 1990 ).
Sabal bracknellense (Chandler) Mai (Fig. 2I-2S )

Basionym. Palmospermum bracknellense Chandler 1961, p. 125, pl. 13, figs. 15, 16 , Sabal bracknellense (Chandler) Mai 1976, p. 104, pl. 2, figs. 5-9. Description. Seeds subglobose, rounded dorsally; proximal surface with a broad circular depression that is domed in the center, 5.1-7.0 mm in diameter and 5.1-6.0 mm in height. Surface smooth to wrinkled. Outline of the germination operculum circular (0.9-2.0 mm diameter), positioned equatorially, subequatorially, or supraequatorially.
Specimens
Localities. TMM 41917, 42534, WPA-1 (Lehman 2007; UF404) .

These seeds are less than half the size of those of S. bigbendense ( fig. 3 ). We cannot distinguish them morphologically or in size from seeds of S. bracknellense from the Eocene of Europe and Oregon (Mai 1976; Manchester 1994 ), a species with seeds resembling extant Sabal minor (Jacq.) Persoon ( fig. 3 ). Because we lack any clear morphological distinction from the Eocene representatives, we are hesitant to coin a new species name for the Aguja representatives and have assigned them to the same species as the Eocene European specimens. It is likely, however, that the populations would be found to rep-resent distinct species if other parts of the plants, such as the flowers and frond tips, were available for direct comparison.

Both of these species of fossil seeds are indistinguishable in morphology from those of extant Sabal. The shared characters include thin testa, subglobose to oblate (not elongate) shape, rounded distal surface, domed proximal truncation with chalaza and raphe, and small circular outline of the embryo radicle protrusion located at the equator or offset toward the distal pole. These are all features that Mai (1976) indicated as characteristic of the genus. Descriptions of the position of the embryo scar have varied in the literature as a result of conflicting interpretations of ''which way is up.'' Paleobotanists have referred to the position of this scar as equatorial to subequatorial, treating the prominent hilar cavity as the apical end of the seed, whereas neobotanists refer to the position as equatorial to supraequatorial or subapical, treating the hilar scar as basal (Zona 1990; Dransfield et al. 2008) . Despite apparent differences from the descriptions, when orientations are treated consistently, the position of the embryo corresponds in the fossil and extant Sabal seeds. Here we treat the hilum as basal and the embryo position as equatorial to supraequatorial.

Being concerned that identical seed morphology might occur in other genera of palms, we examined seeds of a wide range of extant genera in the palm collection of the Bailey Hortorium, Cornell University, with the latest systematic treatments (Asmussen et al. 2006; Dransfield et al. 2008 ) as a guide. The latter reference provides descriptions and diagrammatic illustrations of seeds throughout the family. In the revised classification of palms provided by Asmussen et al. (2006) , including relationships inferred from molecular sequence data, Sabal is treated as the only member of tribe Fig. 3 Plot of seed diameter ranges for selected extant and fossil species of Sabal. Data from Mai (1976) , Zona (1990) , and Manchester (1994) . Superscripts 1 and 2 indicate Aguja and Eocene specimens, respectively.

INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF PLANT SCIENCES Sabalinae (tribe Corypheae) and sister to the subtribe Thrinacinae (including Chelyocarpus, Coccothrinax, Cryosophila, Hemithrinax, Itaya, Schippia, Thrinax, Trithrinax, Zombia). These two groups are sister to all remaining Coryphoideae, which is now considered to be a morphologically diverse group including not only Corypha but also, for example, Phoenix, Rhapis, Rhapidophyllum, Trachycarpus, Chamaerops, Brahea, Serenoa, Colpothrinax, Pritchardia, Washingtonia, Livistona, Copernicia, Bismarckia, Satranala, Hyphaene, Medemia, Borassodendron, Borassus, Lodoicea, Latania, Corypha, and Caryota. The seed morphology of Sabal appears to be unique among these and other clades of the palm family. Seeds of the sister subtribe, Thrinaceae, are globose to slightly prolate, without the prominent basal depression, and in some genera are prominently grooved (Dransfield et al. 2008) . Among the other Coryphoidieae, seeds of Washingtonia are similarly smooth and shiny with a prominent concavity, but the concavity is lateral rather than basal, and the seed is ellipsoidal rather than oblate. Given the apparent uniqueness of Sabal seeds and the phylogenetic separation of this genus from other Coryphoid palms, it seems reasonable to place these Cretaceous seeds in the extant genus.

Aside from the size differences, Sabal bigbendesnse and Sabal bracknellense seeds are morphologically very similar. Indeed, there could be some concern that these two sizes of seeds from the Agua Formation merely represent variant seeds from a single species. However, the size ranges do not overlap, and the disparity in size would be sufficient to distinguish among different extant species ( fig. 3 ). In addition, we have not observed obvious bimodality in distribution of seed size within or between separate trees of the same species in extant Sabal.

The palm stems that co-occur with the Sabal seeds and juvenile dinosaur remains are relatively uniform in anatomy ( fig.  4 ). The stems typically range from 10 to 20 cm in diameter, and their preserved length varies from less than 20 up to 150 cm. Cortical and dermal zones are absent in the samples we examined. The collateral vascular bundles have fibrous bundle sheaths that are much larger than the vascular bundles. Some bundles have only protoxylem; more commonly, the bundles have one, two, or three large metaxylem vessels. There is a single phloem strand per bundle. The ground tissue is not lacunose and includes tabular parenchyma, sometimes encircling the bundles and sometimes radiating from the bundles.

Most fossil palm stems have been assigned to the genus Palmoxylon Schenk. Uhlia allenbyensis Erwin and Stockey (1994) is an exception. This species is based on stem fragments with attached petioles, which showed features of systematic value, allowing assignment of this Eocene palm to subfamily Coryphoideae, tribe Corypheae. The anatomy of palm stems varies considerably even within a single individual, both horizontally and vertically, and is affected by stem age (Tomlinson 1990) . This variability makes it difficult to assign isolated palm stem fragments to individual genera. It has long been recognized that assigning fossil palm stems to extant genera or groups of genera is difficult because systematically diagnostic characters have not been found for many groups. Kaul (1960) , who reviewed earlier work on palm anatomy, remarked that there were no workable natural or artificial classifications for fossil palm stem anatomy. Nambudiri and Tidwell (1998) reviewed the characteristics used in classifying Palmoxylon species. They found that some of the features previously used to distinguish Palmoxylon species were features of dubious taxonomic value because they were affected by position within the stem.

For these Aguja palm stems our objectives were to determine (1) whether their anatomy is consistent with the anatomy of Sabal and other coryphoid palms and (2) whether they resemble palms from the nearby late Campanian-early Maastrichtian Olmos Formation of northern Mexico (Cevallos-Ferriz and Ricalde-Moreno 1995). According to Tomlinson (1961) the sabaloid palm group has well-developed fibrous bundle sheaths, undivided phloem bundles, and xylem surrounded by parenchyma; within the group the number of metaxylem vessels per bundle is variable. The Aguja palms also have these features. These traits are not exclusive to the sabaloid palms; nevertheless, they do not contradict the evidence from seeds and foliage for the recognition of Sabal in the Aguja flora. The Olmos Formation shares some dicot genera with the Aguja and Javelina formations of Big Bend (Wheeler and Lehman 2009) , so it is possible that there also are shared monocots. Four Palmoxylon species have been reported from the Olmos Formation (Cevallos-Ferriz and Ricalde-Moreno 1995): Palmoxylon longum, Palmoxylon commune, Palmoxylon fibrosum, and Palmoxylon polymorphum. The size of fibrous bundle sheaths and some features of ground tissue parenchyma in P. commune and P. fibrosum are similar to those of the Aguja palms.

The Aguja palm leaves ( fig. 4F, 4G ) fit the concept of Sabalites Saporta as summarized by Read and Hickey (1972, p. 133) in a review of morphogenera for fossil palm leaves: ''Unarmed, palmate leaf fossils exhibiting a condition wherein the petiole appears to extend into the blade (costapalmate), with the fused segments and their midveins emerging at an acute angle and extending straight away from the costa toward the leaf apex. Adaxial surface of the leaves may exhibit a 'hastula' or ligule-like appendage at the junction of petiole and blade.'' Among extant palms, leaves fitting this description occur in various other predominantly coryphoid genera, in addition to Sabal (Dransfield et al. 2008) , so the morphogenus Sabalites should not be equated with Sabal. Dorf (1939) assigned the Aguja fossils to the genus Sabalites and indicated relationships with the subfamily Sabaleae rather than direct assignment to the extant genus Sabal because he considered that other genera of the subfamily are also similar. Daghlian (1978) recognized the extant genus Sabal, as well as the morphogenera Sabalites, Costapalma Daghlian, and Palustrapalma Daghlian, from Eocene fronds with well-preserved epidermal anatomy. However, these Cretaceous Aguja leaf fossils, known only from impressions, without epidermal anatomy, should be retained in the morphogenus Sabalites. Nevertheless, we hypothesize that these leaves were produced, along with the Palmoxylon stems, by the same plants that shed the Sabal seeds described here.

Although confined to the New World in modern distribution, Sabal was more widespread in the Northern Hemisphere during the Tertiary, with records confirmed by seeds from the Early Eocene of southern England (Reid and Chandler 1933) and the Middle Eocene of Germany (Mai 1976) . Dransfield et al. (2008) reviewed the fossil record for Sabal and Sabalites. The oldest verified occurrence of Sabalites is Sabalites carolinensis leaves from the Coniacean-Santonian of eastern North America (Berry 1914; Kva cek and Herman 2004) ; these are the oldest unequivocal fossils of Arecaceae (Harley 2006) . Other Late Cretaceous records include palm leaves referred to as Sabalites longirhachis (Unger) J. Kva cek et Herman from the Campanian of Austria (Kva cek and Herman 2004). Sabal and sabaloid fossils are also known from the Tertiary to Holocene from a variety of sites that are not only within but also well outside the current range of the genus, e.g., Great Britain (Reid and Chandler 1933) , Oregon (Manchester 1994) , Kentucky, Tennessee, Texas (Daghlian 1978) , China, and Japan (Zona 1990 ). The Asian occurrences are based only on leaves without epidermal anatomy and have not been confirmed by seeds and should be treated in the morphogenus Sabalites, but we accept the European seed records as valid representatives of the extant genus Sabal. Its range diminished after the terminal Eocene cooling, and the genus was eradicated from Europe after the Miocene.

Because of the fossil evidence and relationships within the genus, Zona (1990) hypothesized that Sabal probably had a Laurasian origin. More recent work also suggests a Laurasian origin for coryphoid palms (Bjorholm et al. 2006) . Lehman (1985) interpreted the palm-bearing part of the Aguja upper shale member as consisting of deltaic interdistributary marsh and coastal floodplain deposits, accumulated immediately landward of the shoreline. This sedimentary facies association is compatible with the coastal environments favored by some modern Sabal species, e.g., Sabal maritima (Kunth) Burret (Wade and Langdon 1990; Zona 1990 ). The palm seeds and stems are found in association with two of the typical Aguja wood assemblages recognized by Wheeler and Lehman (2000, 2005) : the platanoid-icacinoid assemblage, which consists predominantly of small, slender axes of low-growing shrubs or scrambling vines, and the cupressoidpodocarpoid ''acme'' zone, which is dominated by ''logjam'' accumulations of large conifer trunks. The occurrence of palm stems and seeds in association with both of these wood assemblages suggests that palms may have grown in areas bordering both vegetational facies, for example, in the same way that modern Sabal palmetto (Walt.) Lodd. ex J. A. & J. H. Schulz. in Florida grows in ''hammocks'' between salt marshes and stands of cypress or pine forest (Wade and Langdon 1990) . A similar setting was envisioned by Wing et al. (1993) , who documented palmetto-dominated vegetation based on an in situ assemblage of diverse leaf remains from a delta plain environment in the early Maastrichtian or late Campanian Meeteetse Formation of Wyoming.

It is significant that juvenile certatopsian and hadrosaurian dinosaur skeletal material occurs in association with these Sabal seeds, at all four sites. For example, one of the Sabal bracknellense seeds was found at the WPA (UF404) quarry site, described by Lehman (2007) , that preserves a mass mortality assemblage of the ceratopsian Chasmosaurus mariscalensis Lehman. The skeletal material consists mostly of disarticulated limb and girdle elements and vertebral centra ( fig. 5 ). Apart from their small size, the isolated bones are identifiable as juvenile on the basis of their cortical bone texture and open neurocentral sutures. The skeletal elements belong to individuals of varied sizes. For example, identifiable elements recovered at TMM 42534 represent individuals from 26% to 70% adult size ( fig. 5 ). Hence, young animals of varied ages inhabited or were preserved at these sites. Juvenile dinosaurs are otherwise quite rare in the Aguja Formation. This co-occurrence led Lehman (2002) to suggest that there may have been an ecological relationship between palms and juvenile dinosaur herbivores. Some of these fossil Sabal seeds show apparent pre-or paradepositional breakage, but there are no obvious bite marks, and it is unclear whether the breakage was biologically or physically induced. Barrett and Willis (2001) and Butler et al. (2009) reviewed evidence for coevolutionary interaction between angiosperms and herbivorous dinosaurs but found little support in either the times of appearance or the diversification patterns of major plant and dinosaur clades to indicate that dinosaurs played a significant role in the adaptive radiation of flowering plants. Lecky and Tiffney's (2002) review of the North American record found that hadrosaurians tend to co-occur with floras with a high percentage of angiosperms. Whether by intensity of browsing, environmental disturbance (''dinoturbation''), or acting as seed dispersal agents, it seems certain that large dinosaurian herbivores exerted some influence on the vegetative structure and composition of Mesozoic plant communities. The wide taxonomic variety of dinosaur Fig. 5 Typical juvenile ceratopsian and hadrosaur skeletal elements from TMM 42534. The length of each element expressed as a percentage of adult length (in parentheses) is determined on the basis of comparison with the largest specimens from the Aguja Formation attributed to Chasmosaurus mariscalensis (Lehman 2007) and to ?Kritosaurus sp. (Davies 1983) . A, Ceratopsian right scapula (26%) in lateral view. B, Ceratopsian right scapula (29%) in lateral view. C, Hadrosaur right astragalus (36%) in proximal and anterior views. D, Hadrosaur right astragalus (50%) in proximal and anterior views. E, Ceratopsian proximal caudal vertebral centrum (42%) in anterior, left lateral, and dorsal views. F, Ceratopsian proximal caudal vertebral centrum (70%) in anterior, left lateral, and dorsal views. G, Hadrosaur anterior dorsal vertebral centrum (45%) in anterior, left lateral, and dorsal views. H, Hadrosaur anterior dorsal vertebral centrum (59%) in anterior, left lateral, and dorsal views.
herbivores and their varied dentition and jaw occlusion mechanisms further suggest that each may have specialized in processing different sorts of plant food.

Because of their great stature, large gut capacity, and high dietary demands, adult dinosaurian herbivores are generally considered to have been ''bulk feeders'' and rather indiscriminant browsers (Farlow 1987; Tiffney 2004) . However, direct evidence of the kinds of plant tissues they consumed is scant. Putative gut contents preserved within articulated skeletons of several Late Cretaceous hadrosaurs contain wood, leaf cuticle, and seeds of both gymnosperms and angiosperms, but it is possible that these tissues instead represent detritus washed into the abdominal cavities with sediment during burial (Currie et al. 1996) . More definitive gut contents preserved within an ankylosaur skeleton include vascular tissue, foliage, and seeds of angiosperms (Molnar and Clifford 2000) . Coprolites attributed to hadrosaurs on the basis of their size, form, and spatial association with skeletal remains contain fragments of gymnosperm wood, foliage, and seeds (Chin and Gill 1996; Baghai-Riding and DiBenedetto 2001; Tweet et al. 2008) . Some coprolites possibly attributable to dinosaurian herbivores contain leaf cuticle, stem fragments, and abundant small angiosperm seeds (Nambudiri and Binda 1989; Rodriguez de la Rosa et al. 1998) . Such evidence may support the notion that dinosaurs were indiscriminant browsers and only facultative seed dispersal agents (Tiffney 2004) . Zona (1990) summarized observations on the ecology of modern Sabal, and several of the attributes seem well suited for an environment inhabited by large herbivores. Sabal species have a high tolerance for disturbance and are widespread in disrupted lowland areas, thriving as an invasive ''weed'' today in anthropogenic habitats. They can withstand burning and even persist after clearing for agriculture (Zona 1990 ). The aerial stem arises only after many years of underground growth; the underground stem may be vital in allowing Sabal to withstand disturbance and to rapidly colonize open areas. The high tolerance for disturbance exhibited by Sabal may have initially evolved as an adaptation to the presumably large ecological ''footprint'' of dinosaurian herbivores, in the manner hypothesized by Bakker (1978) .

cite_spans.text: Rodriguez de la Rosa et al. 1998)

body_text.text: However, most such observations and discussion of dinosaurplant interactions emphasize the stature of adult dinosaurian ''megaherbivores'' and their likely high or low browsing ranges without considering the much greater numbers of juvenile dinosaurs that must have fed directly on or very near the ground. In addition, given the communal nesting behavior evident in some dinosaurian herbivores and the absence of other small ground-dwelling herbivores in Mesozoic ecosystems, infant dinosaur ''rookeries'' may have placed quite a heavy demand on plant materials close to the ground. And, if young dinosaur herbivores had high metabolic rates and rapid growth rates, their plant food diets must have been of high energy value compared to bulk foliage (Lehman 2007) . Therefore, juvenile dinosaur herbivores were likely more specialized in their feeding than adults, and fallen seeds and fruits such as those of palms described herein might have comprised an important food resource for them.

To sustain their presumed high growth rates, young herbivorous dinosaurs, with their limited gut capacities, must have fed selectively on plant parts with high energy value (Farlow 1987) . In Late Cretaceous environments and before the appearance in Paleogene time of large fruits, nuts, and seeds adapted for biotic dispersal in tropical forest dicots, palm fruits could have been an important food resource (Tiffney 1984) . In modern tropical ecosystems, palm fruits are consumed by a wide variety of arboreal herbivores (birds, bats, squirrels, and monkeys), but so many fruits are produced that they are also eaten by terrestrial herbivores (rodents, pigs, deer, cattle, tapir; Corner 1966; Kahn and de Granville 1992) . A nutritional analysis of Sabal seeds determined that they are suitable for feeding pigs and ruminants (Arellano et al. 1992 ). There were few, perhaps no, arboreal herbivores in Late Cretaceous environments, and juvenile herbivorous dinosaurs were probably the most abundant small terrestrial herbivores. The beaks and shearing teeth of ceratopsians and hadrosaurs would have been well suited for gaining hold of and crushing the relatively tough palm fruits. Cretaceous palmetto palms, if they grew in dense ''thickets,'' as in some modern settings, would also have provided protective cover for the juvenile dinosaur herbivores.

Modern palm seeds are also spread by floodwaters (Corner 1966) , so it is possible that accumulations of palm seeds with bones of juvenile dinosaurs could have resulted from hydraulic concentration. Indeed, at two of the sites (TMM 43163 and 41917) the seeds and bones occur in a fluvial sandstone bed, along with abraded tooth, bone, and wood fragments indicative of transport. However, at the other sites (TMM 42534 and WPA-1) the sedimentary matrix consists of finegrained organic-rich mudstone, accumulated in quiescent environments. At all four of these sites, bones of adult dinosaurs are also found, which together with the small seeds and juvenile dinosaur remains do not comprise a group of hydraulically equivalent objects. Hence, concentration by running water alone cannot explain these accumulations. We infer, therefore, that the association of palms with juvenile ceratopsians and hadrosaurs cannot be attributed simply to sedimentary sorting.

The frost sensitivity of modern palms limits their worldwide distribution to climates with mean annual temperature (MAT) greater than 10°C, coldest month mean temperature (CMMT) greater than 5°C, and yearly minimum temperature greater than À10°C (Greenwood and Wing 1995) . More specifically, the distribution of Sabal spp. along the Gulf Coast of North America is limited to areas with MAT at least 15°C, having less than a 4-6-d duration of longest annual frost and where CMMT is no colder than 5°-10°C (Greenwood and Wing 1995) . These limitations make the distribution of fossil palms useful as paleoclimate proxy data. Hence, the palm fossils described here may provide insight into the climatic conditions of the Aguja flora and fauna.

The northernmost report of palm foliage during the Campanian-Maastrichtian in the North American interior is from northern Montana (Crabtree 1987) , which would have been ;55°N paleolatitude, based on the paleogeographic map of Scotese (1991; fig. 6 ). Although palm foliage has also been described from the Late Cretaceous of Vancouver Island, British Columbia (Bell 1957 ), at ;60°N paleolatitude, this region 686 INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF PLANT SCIENCES is part of an accreted terrane that has been displaced northward tectonically from its Late Cretaceous position (Wyld et al. 2006) . Palm foliage has not been reported from wellstudied strata of this age in the Dinosaur Provincial Park area of southern Alberta , which was at ;58°N paleolatitude, or from higher latitudes in the interior of North America (Upchurch and Wolfe 1993) . Although pollen with possible palm affinities (e.g., Arecipites) has been reported from southern Alberta (Braman and Koppelhus 2005) , some have argued that these pollen genera may not be useful for paleoclimatic interpretation because plant families other than palms produce structurally identical simple pollen types (Upchurch et al. 1999) . If the northernmost Late Cretaceous limit of preserved palm foliage approximates their actual limit, then that was between 55°and 58°N paleolatitude, and the ;15°C MAT isotherm must have been at about that latitude ( fig. 6 ). The northernmost limit of Late Cretaceous crocodilians in North America is somewhat higher than that inferred for palms, between 58°and 65°N, which should be near the 14°C MAT isotherm (Markwick 1998) . Together, the distribution of palms and crocodilians indicates that the Late Cretaceous MAT at ;60°N was no colder than 15°C.

Palm seeds found in the Aguja Formation are referable with some confidence to the extant genus Sabal. Two distinct size classes among the seeds indicate that two species are represented. This remarkable occurrence reveals that the modern palmetto palms originated over 77 million years ago, shortly after the earliest appearance of palms in the fossil record. Palm leaves and stems morphologically consistent with Sabal also occur within the same stratigraphic interval and at the same sites that yield the seeds. The four seed-bearing sites are particularly notable because they also preserve remains of juvenile ceratopsian and hadrosaurian dinosaurs. Juvenile specimens are rare elsewhere in the Aguja Formation. This co-occurrence likely reflects an ecological association. Palm fruits are an important food resource for arboreal and terrestrial herbivores in modern tropical ecosystems, and fallen fruits would have provided juvenile dinosaurian herbivores with high-energy-value fodder necessary to sustain high growth rates with their limited gut capacities.
Author for correspondence; e-mail: steven@flmnh.ufl.edu.Manuscript received April 2010; revised manuscript received April 2010.

back_matter.text: We thank the Science and Resource Management staff of Big Bend National Park, in particular D. Corrick and S. Wick, for their assistance with our research in the park and J. Browning for discovering several of the palm seeds described herein. David Greenwood and Scott Wing contributed helpful discussion on the climatic requirements of extant palms. Kevin Nixon, Cornell University, provided access to the Bailey Hortorium for comparative study of extant palm fruits and seeds, and Hongshan Wang accessioned and curated the cited fossil Sabal seeds at UF. Scott Wing, Edith Taylor, and Bruce Tiffney provided helpful review comments. This work was supported in part by NSF grant BSR-0743474 to S. R. Manchester.

FIGREF0.text: Fossil and extant Sabal seeds. A-H, Sabal bigbendense sp. nov. from the Aguja Formation. A, B, Basal view showing circular outline and hilar scar and lateral view showing protruding hilum and supraequatorial circular germination operculum scar; UF402-53789. C, D, Basal and lateral views of seed with longitudinally ruptured seed coat; UF403-53792. E-G, Basal, lateral, and apical views, with circular germination operculum. Arrow in G and subsequent illustrations indicates the germination operculum; UF403-53791. H, Specimen with longitudinal fractures; UF403-53793. I-S, Sabal bracknellense (Chandler) Mai from the Aguja Formation. I-K, Basal, apical, and lateral views of seed with fully intact seed coat, showing irregular indentations; UF403-53795. L, M, Basal and lateral views of seed; UF404-53798. N, O, Basal and lateral views of seed; UF403-53794. P, Q, UF401-53784. R, S, Lateral and apical views of seed; UF401-53785. T-V, Extant Sabal palmetto, Gainesville, Florida; basal and lateral views and longitudinal section intercepting the embryo; UF Modern Ref. Coll. 1437. W, X, Basal and lateral views, extant Sabal bermudana Bailey, Bermuda; Bailey sn. Y, Extant Sabal pumos Guerrero, Mexico; Moore 8113.

FIGREF1.text: Palm stems and leaves from the Aguja Formation. A, Palm base preserved in growth position (source of thin section RM-27) at TMM 42534; preserved height is 30 cm. B, Palm base preserved in prone position at TMM 4163; preserved length is 130 cm. C-E, Palmoxylon; RM-27. C, Stem section showing disposition of vascular bundles. D, E, Vascular bundles with large fibrous bundle sheaths. F, G, Sabalites leaf impression in sandstone.
